bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Editors, The Annals, May 24, 1920

div1.p: Carter requests the correction of a typographical error in his article.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Editors, The Annals, May 24, 1920
div1.opener:
Miscl
Y. F-
U. S. Marine Hospital,
/LC
Baltimore, Md.,
May 24, 1920.
The Editors,
School of Tropical Medicine,
The University,
Liverpool, England.
Gentlemen:
div1.p:
In an article: The Mechanism of the Spontaneous Elimination of
Yellow Fever from Endemic Centres, by myself, published in The Annals
of March 15, 1920 there is a typographical error on Page 304, re-
peated on Page 305:

In postulate (1) I wrote “since the parasites in the mosquito
live only during the life of the host, say days, no interval
greater than days” etc. was intended to represent an un-
known but definite number of days. Your printer evidently under-
stood it as the Roman numeral and has written it “ten.” The error
is entirely excusable--nay natural--but to an extent unfortunate,
because the life of the Stegomyia in nature may be well above ten
days and I have had inquiries as to the data on which I predicated
this limit. I judge the fault was my own and in future I will use
“y” or some other letter which has no numerical equivalent in place
of

I will be grateful if you will publish this correction in the
next number of your Annals.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
